summary: This document is a chain of emails from May 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors and FBI personnel regarding logistical and technical challenges in processing and transferring digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. The correspondence focuses on obtaining a complete inventory of seized devices, coordinating data transfers, and resolving significant technical issues with the electronic document review system.

persons.name: Rozier
persons.context: Mentioned as being available to join a conference call to discuss Epstein search warrant documents and evidence processing.

events.title: Follow-up on Epstein evidence inventory
events.description: Email follow-up requesting a list of devices seized from Epstein's residences and from his person upon arrest, needed for an updated search warrant.

events.title: Scheduling conference call on evidence
events.description: Coordination to schedule a conference call for April 8, 2020, to discuss issues with Epstein search warrant documents and evidence processing.

events.title: Complaint about unhelpful evidence spreadsheet
events.description: Prosecutors express that a provided spreadsheet of seized items is not helpful due to mismatched descriptions, lack of cross-reference numbers, and unclear terms like 'loose media'.

events.title: FBI provides listing of transferred data
events.description: An FBI contact provides a listing of what has been handed over in load files for taint review, detailing specific items from the New York apartment and island property.

events.title: Request for detailed evidence spreadsheet
events.description: Prosecutors request a detailed spreadsheet inventorying each device from search warrants, its processing status, and what data has been transferred, to understand the scope of evidence.

events.title: Previous search of Epstein property
events.description: Mention that 9 IDE hard drives found in Epstein's Manhattan apartment in 2020 were copies of drives from a July 2007 search of one of his properties.

locations: USVI (U.S. Virgin Islands, referring to Epstein's island property)
keyFacts: Prosecutors were struggling to obtain a basic, coherent inventory of all electronic devices seized from Epstein's New York and US Virgin Islands residences and from his person at arrest, several months after the seizures.

Significant technical problems were reported with the electronic data received, including an inability to link emails with their attachments, load files not matching native files, and many large files being 'invisible' in the review database, hampering the investigation.
Evidence seized included at least 40+ storage devices from the New York mansion, over 60 CDs, and more than 25 devices (including servers) from the Virgin Islands property.
FBI analysis revealed that 9 hard drives found in the 2020 New York search were copies of drives seized in a previous July 2007 search of an Epstein property.
The correspondence reveals operational challenges within law enforcement, including network outages and reduced staffing ('1 day a week'), impacting the pace of evidence processing in early 2020.
